questions.text: A study compares the body weights of a group of individuals before and after putting them on a special diet. Which of the following tests is used in this case?
questions.solution:
This study involves a quantitative variable, i.e, body weight, and compares the before and after results of the same group. Hence, paired T-test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The dermatologist prescribes an oral fungicidal agent for a patient diagnosed with onychomycosis as shown below. Which of the following options indicate the likely drug used in its treatment along with its mechanism of action?

choices.text: Itraconazole - Binding to ergosterol and altering membrane functions
Amphotericin B - Formation of pore  in cell membrane

questions.solution:
Terbinafine is an oral fungicidal agent and works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis. It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

Squalene epoxidase is an enzyme that converts squalene to squalene epoxide. Terbinafine acts as a non-competitive inhibitor of “squalene epoxidase”, an early-step enzyme in the synthesis of fungal ergosterol. This results in the accumulation of sterol squalene which is toxic to the organism.

Terbinafine is used to treat Onychomycosis by taking 250mg OD tablets for up to 12 weeks in case of toenails. The efficacy is improved when combined with amorolfine 5% nail lacquer in onychomycosis.

It is also used in the treatment of Tinea corporis (2 weeks), Tinea cruris (4-6 weeks), and Tinea capitis (4-8 weeks).

Other options:

Though Amphotericin B acts by forming pores in the membrane, it is not used in dermatophytic infections due to limited activity.

Itraconazole and Griseofulvin are fungistatic against tinea infections.

questions.text: A patient dies of severe congestive heart failure. An autopsy was done, which revealed the following appearance of the aortic valve. Blood investigations were done before death revealed normal levels of serum sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride. Which of the following pathological process likely resulted in the appearance of the aortic valve as shown?
questions.solution:
The image shows extensive calcification of the aortic valve resulting in stenosis. Calcification of the valve, in an elderly patient, with normal serum levels of calcium occurs due to dystrophic calcification.

When the deposition of calcium occurs in dead or dying tissues, it is called dystrophic calcification. This occurs in the absence of derangements in calcium metabolism, i.e the calcium levels are normal. Dystrophic calcification is seen in areas of necrosis of any type including coagulative, caseous, or liquefactive, and in foci of enzymatic fat necrosis.

Some examples include atheromas of advanced atherosclerosis, areas of caseous necrosis in tuberculosis. It also commonly develops in ageing or damaged heart valves.

Other options:

Option A- Cardiac amyloidosis may occur secondary to systemic amyloidosis or as a result of aging (senile amyloidosis). It is associated with the deposition of hyaline, eosinophilic amyloid, in the conduction tissue, interstitium, and coronary vessels. These deposits may be seen on congo-red staining.

Option B- Hemosiderosis is characterized by the deposition of hemosiderin which is one of the major storage forms of iron. This is a hemoglobin-derived golden-yellow colored pigment. The deposition may occur in any organ or tissue. It is seen in conditions associated with iron overload.

Option D- Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues, in the presence of hypercalcemia. It is usually a consequence of excessive parathyroid hormone.

questions.text: An elderly woman who is a known case of uncontrolled diabetes and having a prior history of COVID-19 infection, presents with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose, eye pain, and diplopia. The culture of this discharge on Sabouraud's agar would reveal colonies showing which of the following?

choices.text: Broad hyphae with acute angle branching
Septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. The culture of the discharge on Sabouraud's agar will reveal colonies showing broad hyphae with irregular branching.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, mucor, and lichtheimia. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing infarction, and necrosis. This is responsible for the black foul-smelling discharge seen in this patient. 

Diagnosis can be made by staining them with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as irregularly branched broad hyphae.

The below image shows broad-based irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis.

Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis. Surgical debridement and control of underlying predisposing causes should also be done.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, hemoptysis, evening rise of temperature, and, weight loss. Which of the following drugs used to manage this condition acts by inhibiting RNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Rifampin/Rifampicin is the first-line antitubercular drug that acts by inhibiting RNA synthesis.

Rifampin binds to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis.

Rifampicin is also bactericidal against Mycobacterium leprae.

The usual adult dose of rifampicin for the treatment of tuberculosis is 10 mg/kg (maximum 600 mg daily) given daily or three times weekly by directly observed therapy.

Adverse effects of rifampin are hepatitis, flu-like illness, and urine and secretions may become orange-red but this is harmless. 

Other options:

Option A: Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug inhibits the production of mycolic acid.

Option C: Pyrazinamide is also speculated to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis.

Option D: Ethambutol is a tuberculostatic drug that works by inhibiting arabinosyl transferases, this in turn interferes with mycolic acid incorporation into the mycobacterial cell wall.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male patient presents with a history of decreased vision. On ophthalmoscopic examination, a single micro aneurysm is noted. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient with a single microaneurysm is mild non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy(NPDR).

Diabetic retinopathy is a disease characterized by retinal changes secondary to hyperglycemia.

Diabetic retinopathy is broadly classified into non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy, proliferative diabetic retinopathy, diabetic maculopathy, and advanced diabetic eye disease. Depending on the extent of severity, non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy is further classified into mild, moderate, severe, and very severe.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessley immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes. 
  • Satellite lesions.
  • Thick, non-sterile hypopyon.

Topical drugs such as natamycin, voriconazole, amphotericin B, and nystatin can be used. Systemic antifungal agents such as ketoconazole are used if the ulcers are severe/perforated.

questions.text: The body of a missing person was found tied to a boat. During the autopsy, you notice the presence of the following organism in his brain tissue. Which of the following is not a possible cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a diatom. Postmortem drowning does not show diatoms in the brain tissue.

Diatoms are microscopic unicellular or colonial algae present in water. As the diatoms are found in both seawater and freshwater, their presence cannot differentiate between freshwater and seawater drowning.

The presence of diatoms in the brain tissue is suggestive of antemortem drowning, as only a living person can transport diatoms from the lungs to the viscera via circulation.

questions.text: A young male patient was suspected to have a seminoma of the testis. The mass was surgically removed and the specimen was sent for histopathological analysis. Which among the following findings is most likely to be seen microscopically?

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
Microscopically, seminomas show a fried egg appearance of cells. This refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (around 50% of GCTs). It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and a central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate. It is shown below.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller-Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors, and appear as glomerulus-like structures with a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells in a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells. The image of Reinke crystals is shown below.

Option D: Derivatives of all three germ layers like islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, structures reminiscent of the thyroid gland, bronchial or bronchiolar epithelium, and bits of the intestinal wall embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma may all be seen in a teratoma.

questions.text: Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by_____
questions.solution:
Insulin secretion is normally stimulated by Glucagon like peptide-1(GLP 1).

Glucagon-like peptide–1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) are called incretins and are potent stimulators of insulin secretion. They also inhibit glucagon secretion. They are released in the gastrointestinal tract after a person eats a meal. They then cause an “anticipatory” increase in blood insulin in preparation for the glucose and amino acids to be absorbed from the meal. 

Note: Drugs that mimic the action of incretins are used in the management of diabetes.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the clinic with significant astigmatism. The following finding is noted on closer examination. What is the ideal course of management?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a progressive pterygium causing astigmatism, excision of the pterygium along with conjunctival autograft is the preferred management.

Pterygium is a wing-shaped fold of the conjunctiva extending into the cornea. It is commonly seen in people who live in hot climates and in those who work outdoors.

Clinically the patient may present with symptoms such as: 

  • Cosmetic complaints
  • Foreign body sensation and irritation
  • Defective vision/astigmatism when the pterygium extends into the pupillary area
  • Diplopia

Medical management includes tear substitutes, topical corticosteroids, and sunglasses. Surgical management is preferred in patients with significant cosmetic defects, visual impairment, and other such complications.

Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred technique for most pterygiums. In case of recurrent or large pterygium, surgical excision with amniotic membrane graft and mitomycin C is preferred.

questions.text: An elderly man with a long-standing history of memory loss and behavioral changes passed away. On autopsy, brain atrophy was noted. A histopathology section of his brain showed the following finding. This protein is most likely to be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease and the above image shows neurofibrillary tangles inside the neuron. These are formed from helical filaments of abnormal tau proteins.

In Alzheimer’s disease, neurofibrillary tangles and amyloid plaques are found in the brain, especially in the hippocampus. Neurofibrillary tangles are deposited inside the neurons, whereas amyloid plaques are deposited around the neurons.

Other options:

Option A: Amyloid plaques are made of beta-amyloid precursor protein (APP). They are deposited around the neurons. Amyloid plaque is shown in the image below:

Option B: Prions deposit in the neurons and cause apoptosis. The degeneration of these neurons leads to spongiform encephalopathy. The protein gets deposited as plaques.

The image given below shows the spongiform appearance of the brain seen in prion disease.

Option D: Alzheimer's disease may also have Lewy body. Lewy bodies are formed due to the clumping of abnormal alpha-synuclein protein in the neurons. They predominantly cause Lewy body dementia but can also be found in Parkinson’s and Alzhiemer's disease.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother with complaints of biting his lips and nails. On examination, the child has delayed developmental milestones, spasticity, and dystonia. Nail findings are as shown in the image below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the image showing self-mutilation and laboratory values showing hyperuricemia is most likely suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan disease.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine leading to increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP). Increased PRPP leads to increased purine synthesis, which is later degraded to uric acid. Increased hypoxanthine is also converted to uric acid.

The patients have intellectual disability, behaviors of self-injury like lip and finger biting, developmental delay, muscle dystonia, and extrapyramidal symptoms. 

Diagnosis is made by the elevated levels of uric acid and by HGPRT enzyme assay.

The image given below shows the metabolism of hypoxanthine and guanine by HGPRT.

Other options:

Option A: Autism mainly presents with problems in social communication and social interaction. They have poor verbal and non-verbal communication, absence of eye contact, repetitive behaviors like lining up toys or flipping objects, echolalia, etc. Intellectual impairment may or may not be present.

Option C: Patients with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) present with infections. Diarrhea, pneumonia, otitis media, sepsis, and cutaneous infections are common presentations. It is caused by various genetic mutations that lead to the absence of T and B-cell function. They have a low lymphocyte count.

Option D: Tourette’s disorder is characterized by sudden repetitive, non-rhythmic motor movements or sounds. They present with loud grunting or barking noises or shouting obscene words. Motor tics include tongue protrusion, sniffing, hopping, squatting, blinking, or nodding.

questions.text: A patient presents with findings as shown in the image below: 1) shows the site of the lesion,  2) has loss of proprioception, vibration, and discriminative touch 3) has loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion on the contralateral side. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image along with the features above is diagnostic of Brown Sequard syndrome.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The part marked as 1 is the site of the lesion, at which hemisection of the cord is seen.

The part marked as 2 is the ipsilateral side of the lesion, which has the following features.

  • Loss of proprioception and vibration
  • Loss of discriminative touch
  • Weakness and spastic type of paralysis in certain muscle groups

The part marked as 3 is the contralateral side of the lesion and exhibits the following features

  • Loss of pain and temperature beginning one or two segments below the side of the lesion

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented to the OPD with failure to thrive and a developmental defect of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches and was referred for further evaluation. The Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization ( FISH) findings have been shown in the following image. This syndrome is known as____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 seen on Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) are suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome.

A child with a developmental defect of thymus and deletion of chromosome 22q11.2 points towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome.

In this syndrome, the fourth branchial arch and the derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (which contribute to the formation of the thymus, parathyroids, and heart) develop abnormally. This syndrome is therefore associated with multiple deficits (memorable through the mnemonic CATCH - 22)

Mnemonic CATCH-22:

  • Cardiac abnormality
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Deletion 22q11.2  

Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T-cell immunity can manifest as:

  • T cells are absent in the lymph nodes, spleen, and peripheral blood, and infants with this defect are extremely vulnerable to viral, fungal, and protozoal infections.
  • Patients also are susceptible to infection with intracellular bacteria, because of defective T cell-mediated immunity.
  • B cells and serum immunoglobulins are generally unaffected.

 Other options:

Option A: Williams syndrome occurs due to deletion at chromosome 7. Classical facial features include:

  • Periorbital fullness of subcutaneous tissues,
  • Hypertelorism,
  • A stellate pattern of the iris,
  • Long philtrum,
  • Thick vermillion border of the lips,
  • Wide mouth,
  • Small jaw (elfin facies).

Option B: Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome or Pitt–Rogers–Danks syndrome (PRDS) or Pitt syndrome occurs due to partial deletion or monosomy of chromosome 4. The main features of Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome are typical “Greek helmet” facies secondary to ocular hypertelorism, prominent glabella, and frontal bossing, and microcephaly.

Option D: Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by the partial deletion of the short arm of Chromosome no. 5. Affected children have a cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Transport of lipid-soluble substances across the cell membrane occurs via which of the following?
questions.solution:
Lipid-soluble substances are transported across the cell membrane via diffusion.

Passive diffusion is a process by which a lipid-soluble molecule is able to freely cross in and out of the cell by dissolving itself in the phospholipid bilayer.

Other options:

  • Option A: Exocytosis is a process by which cells actively release substances from their intracellular compartments to the extracellular space. It involves the fusion of vesicles with the cell membrane to release their contents. 

  • Option B: Endocytosis is a process by which cells take in substances from the extracellular space into the cell by forming vesicles at the cell membrane.

  • Option C: Osmosis is the movement of water molecules across a semipermeable membrane in response to differences in solute concentration.

Related Pearl: Transport across the cell membrane

questions.text: During your rural posting, you are asked to educate a small village about the importance of routine antenatal care for pregnant mothers. You want to deliver some statistical data to emphasize its importance. Which of the following is the best method to do so?
questions.solution:
A pictogram is the best method of presenting data to people who cannot understand orthodox charts/ uneducated populations. 

In this method, small pictures or symbols are used to present the data.

The following image shows an example of a pictogram.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: Anaplasia refers to:

choices.text: Variation in cell size and shape
Replacement of one type of cell by other

questions.solution:
Anaplasia refers to a lack of differentiation.

The term anaplasia means to form backward implying a reversal of differentiation to a more primitive level. The extent to which neoplastic cells resemble normal cells, both morphologically and functionally, is called differentiation.

Anaplasia is an important morphological feature of malignant transformation.

The morphological features of malignancy include:

  • Anaplasia
  • Pleomorphism - variation in the size and shape of cells
  • Increased N: C ratio (nucleus: cytoplasmic ratio) - around 1:4 in normal cells, increases to 1:1 in malignant cells
  • Hyperchromasia - coarsely clumped and darkly stained chromatin within irregular nuclei
  • Increased mitosis - atypical, bizarre mitotic figures
  • Loss of polarity - sheets or large masses of tumor cells grow in an anarchic, disorganized fashion

questions.text: A mother brings her son to the OPD after noticing a convergent squint. Leukocoria is noted on examination. Enucleation is done and histological analysis of the specimen revealed Flexner- Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above mentioned features of leukocoria and strabismus along with the presence of Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes are suggestive of a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood. It is associated with germline RB1 mutations. 

The most common presentations are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex/amaurotic cat's eye appearance) and strabismus. Fundus examination is therefore mandatory in all cases of childhood squint.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a characteristic histological feature seen in retinoblastoma. Chemotherapy and enucleation are done depending on the extent of tumor involvement.

Other options

Option B: Congenital toxoplasmosis is associated with bilateral and multiple chorioretinal lesions in the fundus, also involving the macular area.

Option C: Retinopathy of prematurity is a retinal vascular disease seen in premature infants and characterized by defective retinal vascularisation.

Option D: Coats disease is idiopathic retinal telangiectasia characterized by unilateral visual loss, strabismus, and leukocoria. There are no characteristic histological findings in this disease.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine?

choices.text: Binding to tubulin and inhibiting granulocyte migration

questions.solution:
Colchicine acts by binding to tubulin and inhibiting granulocyte migration.

Colchicine produces its anti-inflammatory effects by binding to the intracellular protein tubulin. This prevents the polymerization of tubulin into microtubules which is necessary for leukocyte migration and phagocytosis. Inhibition of microtubule formation prevents granulocyte migration and also arrests cell division at the G1 phase.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with hearing loss for the past 2-3 months and the otoscopic finding is suggestive of serous otitis media. 

The given otoscopic image shows a dull and opaque tympanic membrane with clear effusion.

Serous otitis media is also known as secretory otitis media or mucoid otitis media or glue ear. It is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear is thought to happen due to either malfunctioning (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, palatal defects, tumors of nasopharynx) or increased secretory activity of the eustachian tube (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

It is often seen in children 5-8 years of age. They present with hearing loss not exceeding 40 dB, which is insidious in onset. Speech may be delayed and defective due to hearing loss. Mild earaches with a history of upper respiratory tract infection are usually seen. 

On otoscopy, 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • If the tympanic membrane is transparent fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen

 The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss. X-ray mastoid reveals clouding of air cells. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, antibiotics, and middle ear aeration techniques. 
  • Surgical management includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid, grommet insertion, tympanotomy, or cortical mastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A: Myringitis bullosa is characterized by painful hemorrhagic blebs on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. It occurs due to infection by a virus or mycoplasma. 

Option C: Acute otitis media is an acute infection of the middle ear by pyogenic organisms. It presents with marked earache and hearing loss is seen in later stages. Otoscopy shows a red and bulging tympanic membrane.

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Such questions are permitted during which of the following?
questions.solution:
Leading questions are not allowed in all of the given options except cross-examination, i.e leading questions are allowed during cross-examination.

As per section 141 of the Indian Evidence Act, a leading question is one which is suggestive of the answer that is desired or one which includes a fact and leads to the admitting of a conclusive answer, such as yes or no.

Cross-examination is one wherein the witness is questioned by the opposite party's lawyer, i.e the lawyer for the accused or the defense lawyer. It is undertaken with the objective to demonstrate favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and to discredit the witness.

The sequence of examination while recording evidence is as follows:

  1. Examination-in-Chief/direct examination by the party that summoned the witness to elicit all the facts from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed (option C). The only exception is if the judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile. 
  2. Cross-examination is done by the defence lawyer.
  3. Re-examination is done by the party that summoned the witness to correct or clarify or detail the statements made by the witness during cross-examination. Leading questions are not allowed (option A).

Other options:

Option D: A dying declaration is an oral or written statement made by a person who is dying. The doctor should certify that the person is conscious and with normal mental faculties before the declaration is recorded. It is recorded by the executive magistrate, or a doctor in the presence of two witnesses, if there is no time for the magistrate to come. Leading questions should not be asked.

Failure of the cranial end of the neural tube to close is known as exencephaly. As a result of this, the skull vault does not form. This leaves the malformed brain exposed.

questions.text: A young IT professional with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection has a headache that worsens during office hours. The headache starts upon waking, tends to be at its worst by about midday, and improves as the day progresses. This characteristic periodicity is seen in?
questions.solution:
Headache in frontal sinusitis shows characteristic periodicity, i.e. comes upon waking, gradually increases, reaches its peak by about midday, and then starts subsiding. It is also called an office headache because of its presence only during office hours.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge

  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: An infant is brought with complaints of constant watering of eyes with mucopurulent discharge and a non-pulsatile swelling as shown in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of excessive watering of the eyes and swelling over the lacrimal sac in an infant is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis.

Congenital dacryocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac due to the accumulation of secretions. This occurs secondary to an obstruction along the course of the nasolacrimal duct.

Clinical features are epiphora progressing to mucopurulent discharge, positive regurgitation test, and swelling over the lacrimal sac area.

The treatment plan is decided according to the age at presentation. Massaging over the lacrimal sac and topical antibiotics are used as first-line treatment.

Management

  • Massage over the lacrimal sac area along with topical antibiotics is a conservative management method that can cure symptoms in infants up to 6-9 months
  • Probing of the nasolacrimal duct with Bowman's probe can be attempted if symptoms do not resolve within 6 months. 
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy may be done if the child is brought late or if all other treatment methods fail. 

Other options:

Option A: Anterior encephalocele is a pulsatile swelling in the superomedial part of the orbit. It is caused by the herniation of intracranial content through a congenital defect in the skull.

Option C: Syringomas are benign proliferations of eccrine sweat glands and are noted as multiple small papules. 

Option D: Chalazion is a chronic granulomatous, painless swelling of the Meibomian gland in the eyelid.

questions.text: An elderly male patient is diagnosed with benign prostatic hypertrophy. The physician starts him on tamsulosin. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Tamsulosin acts by selective α1 receptor antagonism.

Tamsulosin is a uroselective α1 blocker that acts by decreasing the tone of prostatic/ bladder neck muscles. This reduces the dynamic obstruction and increases the urinary flow rate. It is used in the treatment of BPH and acute urinary retention. It is taken once a day and preferred in cases with postural hypotension as it has very little effect on BP.

Retrograde ejaculation and floppy iris during cataract surgery are the side effects of this drug.

  Other α1 antagonists used in BPH include

  • Terazosin 
  • Doxazosin 
  • Alfuzosin 

Other options:

Option B:  Selective α1 receptor agonists such as phenylephrine are used as nasal decongestants and also as a mydriatic agent. Midodrine has been used to treat patients with autonomic insufficiency and postural hypotension. 

Option C: Nonselective α receptor antagonism can be seen in drugs such as phenoxybenzamine and phentolamine. They are administered prior to the surgical removal of pheochromocytoma to control the episodes of severe hypertension. They have also been used to manage the cheese reaction occurring in patients who take MAO inhibitors.

Option D: Selective α2 receptor agonists such as clonidine have been used in treating hypertension.

questions.text: A 24-yr-old man presents with an excessive desire for sexual intercourse. What is this called?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of satyriasis. 

Satyriasis refers to uncontrollable or excessive sexual desire (hypersexuality) in males. It is also known as Don Juanism. Don Juan is a legendary, fictional libertine who devoted his life to seducing women.

Other options: 

Option B: Frotteurism is a form of paraphilic disorder wherein the affected male achieves sexual gratification by rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman. 

Option C: Nymphomania refers to excessive sexual desire or hypersexuality in women. It is a form of sexual addiction. 

Option D: Sexual masochism is a form of paraphilia wherein the individual has sexual fantasies or urges that involve acts of being beaten, bound, or humiliated. It is more commonly seen in men.

questions.text:
Identify the type of enzymatic inhibition shown in the image below.

Km: Michaelis constant
questions.solution:
The given image represents the mechanism of non-competitive enzyme inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition, an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site of the enzyme. This leads to a conformational change in the substrate-binding site which prevents the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The free enzyme molecules have the same affinity to the substrate because Km remains the same.

In this type of inhibition, Km remains the same.

In enzyme kinetics, Vmax is the reaction rate when the enzyme is saturated with the substrate. Km (Michaelis constant) is the substrate concentration at which the enzyme achieves ½ Vmax.

Km indicates the affinity of the enzyme to the substrate. 

Other options:

Option A: Feedback inhibition is the process by which the enzyme activity is inhibited by the final product of the biosynthetic pathway.

Option B: Suicide inhibition is an irreversible type of enzymatic inhibition. In this type of inhibition, the inhibitor utilizes the enzyme's own reaction mechanisms to inactivate it. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme and creates a new product which in turn irreversibly binds to the enzyme and inhibits it.

Option C: In competitive inhibition, the inhibitor molecules compete with the substrate molecules for binding with the active site of the enzyme.

questions.text: Zinc is a cofactor of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Zinc acts as a cofactor for carbonic anhydrase.

Zinc is a component of many metalloenzymes including:

  • Carboxypeptidase A
  • Alcohol dehydrogenase
  • Adenosine deaminase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • Phospholipase C
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Lactate dehydrogenase

Zinc also has antioxidant activity as extracellular superoxide dismutase is zinc-dependent.

Clinical correlation:

  • Chronic zinc deficiency can cause stunted growth, decreased taste sensation(hypogeusia), impaired immune function and hypogonadism, and hypopigmented hair.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption.

 Note: 

  • The cofactor of xanthine oxidase is molybdenum.
  • The cofactor of lysyl oxidase is copper.
  • The cofactor of glutathione peroxidase is selenium.

questions.text: The histopathological section of the cardiac tissue of an elderly man shows some pigmentation as seen below. Which of the following intracellular accumulations is it likely to be?
questions.solution:
The brown intracellular accumulation that can be seen in this patient is lipochrome (lipid). It is also known as lipofuscin or wear-and-tear pigment.

It is brownish-yellow, granular intracellular material, which accumulates in various tissues like the heart, liver, and brain. It is seen in normal ageing patients. The brown pigment in large amounts can give a characteristic appearance to the tissue called brown atrophy.  

Lipofuscin (brown lipid):

  • Derived through lipid peroxidation of polyunsaturated lipids of subcellular membranes.
  • Not injurious to the cell or its functions.
  • Indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation.
  • Seen in cells undergoing slow, regressive changes.
  • Prominent in the liver, brain, and heart of ageing patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia.

Other options:

Option A: Dutcher bodies are pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C: Mallory bodies are seen in

  1. Alcoholic steatohepatitis
  2. Wilson disease
  3. Primary biliary cirrhosis
  4. Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH)
  5. Hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Option D: Cholesterol deposits are seen in atherosclerosis, xanthomas.

questions.text: A young HIV-positive patient presents with complaints of fever and neck stiffness. The patient's cerebrospinal fluid sample when stained with India ink reveals the following finding. The organism responsible for this infection is transmitted by which of the following methods?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. This organism is usually transmitted through inhalation but occasionally also through skin and mucosa.

Cryptococcus neoformans is a round/ovoid budding cell with a prominent polysaccharide capsule. This capsule can be visualized with the assistance of the India ink stain.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are opportunistic infections seen in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). Patients present with symptoms such as fever/headache. Patients are treated with a combination of Amphotericin with flucytosine.

Other options:

Option A: Diseases such as Lyme disease and Q fever are transmitted by the bite of ixodid ticks.

Option B: Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.

Option D: Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds.

questions.text: A young female patient presents to your clinic with nasal obstruction. Physical examination revealed a wide, roomy nasal cavity, a pale nasal mucosa, and greyish-black dry crusts that improved after modified Young's procedure. Identify the clinical feature likely to be associated with this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis, and merciful anosmia is associated with this condition. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. The patient presents with nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers. It is associated with foul odor from their nose but the patient is unable to smell it because of merciful anosmia. Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements. On examination nasal mucosa appears pale, greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. 

Medical management is done using warm saline for nasal irrigation, removal of crusts and administering local antibiotics like kemicetine antiozaena solution(containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2).

Surgical management involves:

  • In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months and during this time, the mucosa comes back to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young operation is a modified version of Young's operation where the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same compared to Young's operation and it is done to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. 

Other options:

Option A: Offensive cheesy discharge is seen in an uncommon condition called rhinitis caseosa. It is usually unilateral and affects males. The disease arises from chronic sinusitis with the collection of inspissated cheesy material.

Option C: Paroxysmal sneezing refers to bouts of sneezing in the morning and is associated with allergic rhinitis and vasomotor rhinitis. 

Option D: Allergic salute is the constant upward rubbing motion of the nose simulating a salute, leading to transverse nasal crease across the dorsum of the nose. Seen in allergic rhinitis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: Slow waves of peristalsis are generated by:
questions.solution:
The interstitial cells of Cajal undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that peri­odically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that generate slow-wave activity.

Interstitial cells of Cajal are the pacemaker cells of the GIT that initiate the basic electrical rhythm (BER). These are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features.

In the stomach and the small intestine, these cells are located in the circular smooth muscle layer near the myenteric plexus. In the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer.

The slow waves usually do not by themselves cause muscle contraction in most parts of the gastrointestinal tract, except perhaps in the stomach. Instead, they mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction.

Note: Gastrointestinal stromal tumors arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a  history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets.  Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to iron toxicity, which is managed with deferoxamine (also known as desferrioxamine).

Large amounts of ferrous salts can be fatal in children. Initial symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. In severe cases, cyanosis and hyperventilation due to metabolic acidosis can develop. This can sometimes be followed by an asymptomatic phase. Later, hypoglycemia and hepatic and renal failure can develop. Pyloric stenosis and gastric scarring can develop due to its corrosive nature. Ultimately, if left untreated, the child can die.

The gastric contents can be used for an iron color test to estimate the iron concentration in plasma. As iron tablets are radiopaque, an X-ray can be used to assess the number of pills taken. Deferoxamine, an iron chelator has to be administered intramuscularly. Side effects include pruritus, wheals, rash, and anaphylaxis. 

Deferiprone and deferasirox are other oral iron chelators used to treat iron overload in thalassemia patients. 

Other options:

Option B: Activated charcoal can be used in the initial management of acetaminophen and opioid overdose. It is used for gastrointestinal decontamination to prevent further absorption of the poison.

Option C: Dimercaprol, also known as BAL (British anti-Lewisite), is used to treat arsenic, mercury poisoning, and Wilson's disease.

Option D: D-penicillamine (Cuprimine) can be used to treat scleroderma, Wilson's disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. Side effects include nephrotoxicity, hematologic derangements, and a characteristic rash that involves the neck and axillae—elastosis perforans serpiginosa. It is associated with membranous glomerulonephritis, drug-induced lupus, and myasthenia gravis.

It is an autosomal recessive condition due to a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase (also called homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase).

questions.text: A middle-imaged female patient presents to the clinic with sudden onset mild ptosis, decreased sweating on the same side, and anisocoria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in a patient with sudden onset mild ptosis, decreased sweating on the same side and anisocoria is Horner syndrome.

Horner syndrome is also termed oculosympathetic palsy. Presentation depends on the level of lesion in the sympathetic chain.

Patients commonly present with symptoms such as

  • Mild ptosis
  • Anisocoria (difference in size of the pupils) accentuated in dim light
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating

Tests with topical apraclonidine and cocaine can be used to confirm a diagnosis of Horner syndrome.

Other options

Option A: Adie's tonic pupil is caused by damaged sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle following a viral illness. Patients present with large regular pupils that have absent/sluggish light reflexes.

Option C: Bell's palsy is an idiopathic facial palsy affecting lower motor neurons. There is an ipsilateral restriction of eye closure and facial muscle weakness.

Option D: Argyll Robertson pupil is caused by neurosyphilis. On examination, there are irregular small pupils that do not change in size in bright light. However, they constrict on accommodation.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

Septal hematoma occurs when there is an accumulation of blood beneath the periosteum or perichondrium of the nasal septum. The most common cause of hematoma is nasal surgery or trauma. However, it is also seen in individuals with bleeding disorders. 

Patients present with bilateral nasal obstruction, frontal headache, and pressure sensation over the bridge. 

Examination, as seen in this patient, will show bilateral smooth rounded swellings of the nasal septum. If palpated, the mass will be soft and fluctuant.

The following image shows the bilateral, smooth, rounded swellings of the nasal septum indicative of septal hematoma. 

Treatment of septal hematomas involves aspiration with a wide bore needle if small, and incision and drainage if large. The incision can be made parallel to the nasal floor. Removing a small piece of nasal mucosa will aid in drainage. After drainage, the nose has to be packed bilaterally to avoid reaccumulation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Septal abscess occurs usually when there is a secondary infection of a septal hematoma. It is characterized by fever, chills, and frontal headaches. 

Option C - Septal perforation can occur after nasal surgery. Features depend on the size of the perforation. Smaller perforations can present with whistling while the larger perforations will present with epistaxis and crust formation. An image of septal perforation is given below.

Option D - Septal deviation is characterized by chronic unilateral or bilateral nasal obstruction. There is usually an external deformity and associated sinusitis, epistaxis, and anosmia.

questions.text: A young intravenous drug abuser presents with a 1-week history of malaise, fatigue, and rigors. On examination, a high-pitched murmur was heard loudest at the fourth intercostal space in the parasternal region and a cutaneous lesion as seen in the image below was observed. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is infective endocarditis. The most common cause of this disease in intravenous drug users is Staphylococcus aureus.

Infective endocarditis is caused due to an infection of cardiac valves. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus.

Infective endocarditis in patients who inject drugs commonly affects the tricuspid valve. In the case of tricuspid regurgitation patients present with high-pitched murmur heard loudest at the fourth intercostal space in the parasternal region.

The image in the vignette is of Osler's nodes. Osler nodes are painful, with raised lesions of the fingers, toe, and feet. They are peripheral lesions seen in patients with infective endocarditis. 

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought with complaints of excessive watering of the eyes and photophobia. On examination, you note the following. Intraocular pressure is measured to be 30mm of Hg. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of excessive watering, photophobia, enlarged eyeballs with a bluish discoloration, and increased IOP suggests a likely diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma is a condition characterized by high intraocular pressure that occurs due to a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. 

The child presents with lacrimation, photophobia, and blepharospasm. It may also present with buphthalmos. This refers to a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP before 3 years of age. The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Haab striae (curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane) and corneal haze (due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP) may also be noted on examination. 

Initially, an IOP measurement is performed (10–12 mmHg is normal). A corneal diameter measuring greater than 12 mm is highly suggestive of congenital glaucoma.

Management is essentially surgical and involves either goniotomy and/or trabeculotomy. 

Other options:

Option B: Retinoblastoma presents around 1 - 2 years of age. The most common clinical features are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and strabismus. 

Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy presents with visual impairment and corneal clouding due to focal/diffuse thickening of the Descemet membrane.  

Option D: Ehlers–Danlos syndrome type VI (ocular sclerotic form) is an inherited disease of impaired collagen formation. Ocular manifestations are scleral fragility, blue sclera, microcornea, ectopia lentis, myopia, and retinal detachment.

questions.text: A patient in the medicine ward is diagnosed with carcinoid syndrome. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A young boy in the emergency department was brought with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, he has extensive submandibular and cervical swelling. The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin and not bacteremia. 

Treatment of diphtheria includes the administration of diphtheria anti-toxin. Recommended antibiotics include penicillin G and erythromycin.

questions.text: Which of the following animal is not a known reservoir for the monkeypox virus?
questions.solution:
Lizards are not a known reservoir for the monkeypox virus.

Monkeypox is a zoonotic disease caused by a DNA virus (Orthopoxvirus genus of the Poxviridae family). The disease is self-limiting with signs and symptoms lasting between 2-4 weeks. Although the disease has commonly affected West and central Africa, WHO declared it a public health emergency of international concern on 23rd July 2022 amid its outbreak in over 70 countries. India has currently reported 4 cases with the 1st case detected in Kerala.

Transmission 

The disease is transmitted via direct contact with respiratory secretions, blood, body fluids, and skin or mucosal lesions of infected animals or humans. 

Individuals at risk

  • Children <8 years of age
  • Immunocompromised individuals
  • Pregnant and lactating women
  • Men having sex with men 

Clinical features

Incubation period: 6-13 days

1) Invasive period (0-5 days): 

  • Lymphadenopathy 
  • Fever
  • Headache 
  • Myalgia and asthenia

2) Skin eruption (1-3 days within the occurrence of fever):

  • Centrifugal rashes
  • Sequence of rash formation: macule→papules→vesicles→pustules→crusts
  • Site of distribution: face> palms and soles> oral mucous membranes> genitalia> conjunctiva> cornea

Complications include secondary infections, bronchopneumonia, sepsis, encephalitis and loss of vision (corneal involvement).

Since this is a novel disease, studies are being conducted on the natural history of this disease. Currently, known animal reservoirs for this virus are:

  • Squirrels
  • Rats and other rodents such as gerbils
  • Monkeys and other primates
  • Prairie dogs

questions.text: Which among the following is a role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA)?

choices.text: Review and consolidate reports received from the health workers
Supervise deliveries conducted by dais and assist them
Organize and conduct tubectomy and vasectomy camps
Act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits

questions.solution:
It is the role of an accredited social health activist (ASHA) is to act as a depot holder for essential provisions such as condoms and drug kits.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with formal education of up to eighth grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Other roles of ASHA:

  • To create awareness and provide information to the community on nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices
  • To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception
  • To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract /sexually transmitted infection 
  • To facilitate access to health care and healthcare-related services.
  • To arrange an escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility
  • To inform the sub-center/primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community.
  • To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign.

 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: A young girl was rushed to the emergency room in a delirious state. Her parents reported her to have consumed a wild fruit as shown below while on a camping trip. On examination, photophobia, staggering gait, flushing, and dry mucous membranes are noticed. The pupils are bilaterally dilated. Which of the following plant poisons she may have consumed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing cherry-like fruit is suggestive that the plant poison the patient may have consumed is Atropa belladonna. 

Atropa belladonna is a deliriant poison that acts by inhibiting the muscarinic effects of acetylcholine. All the parts of the plants are toxic. The active principle is 1-hyoscyamine.

Clinical manifestations of Atropa belladonna poisoning include: 

  • Fever, flushing, rash
  • Neurological symptoms - delirium, slurred speech, headache, choreoathetosis, myoclonus, visual and auditory hallucinations, convulsions and coma
  • Eye symptoms - photophobia, blurred vision, dilated pupils poorly reactive to light
  • Cardiovascular symptoms - arrhythmia, tachycardia, hypertension
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms - severely dry mouth and throat, decreased bowel sounds, constipation, ileus
  • Renal symptoms - urinary retention

Anticholinergic symptoms include tachycardia, hypertension, flushing, dry mouth, mydriasis and urinary retention.

questions.text: A young male patient presents to the outpatient department with the fear of having tuberculosis reinfection. The patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis 2 years back and had completed the recommended treatment. What test can be done on this patient to detect latent tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Interferon-gamma release assay(IGRA) is used to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection.

In IGRA, sensitized T lymphocytes (from whole blood) of suspected individuals, are exposed to highly specific M.tuberculosis antigens such as CFP –10 and ESAT 6 which leads to the release of the high level of IFN- gamma.

Latent tuberculosis is a state of continuous immune activation by mycobacterial antigens without any clinically active symptoms. Since there are no active symptoms and detection of the organism is difficult, it is detected using immune responses to specific tuberculosis antigens. Tuberculin skin testing and IGRA are used to diagnose latent tuberculosis. In a country like India where there is extensive coverage of the BCG vaccine, IGRA is preferred over tuberculin skin testing due to increased specificity.

questions.text: Folate trap occurs due to the deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
Folate trap occurs in the deficiency of Vitamin B12.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF(methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate that cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap.

Folate cycle provides a link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, where vitamin B12 deficiency causes a functional deficiency of folate.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of abnormal skin pigmentation over his forearms and face. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. Which stain has been used to identify his condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features suggest a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. Prussian blue stain is used to identify this condition. On this stain, the hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes appear blue in color. 

Hemochromatosis occurs due to excessive iron absorption that leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs. It involves liver, pancreas, myocardium,endocrine organs (pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid, and parathyroid glands), joints and skin.

It can be primary hemochromatosis (inherited disorder) or secondary hemochromatosis (accumulation of iron due to other causes). The adult form of primary hemochromatosis usually occurs due to mutations of the HFE gene.

Clinical features include:

  • Abdominal pain, hepatomegaly
  • Diabetes mellitus due to the destruction of pancreatic islets
  • Slate-grey color skin pigmentation due to increased melanin production
  • Cardiac dysfunction (arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy)
  • Acute synovitis due to excessive deposition of calcium pyrophosphate that produces disabling polyarthritis known as pseudogout
  • Atrophic testes secondary to pituitary involvement

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 304-B of the Indian penal code. Which of the following offenses has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
He has been accused of and arrested for dowry death. Section 304-B of the Indian Penal Code (I.P.C) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Other options:

Option C: Culpable homicide is punishable by Sec. 299 IPC. It is an offense wherein the accused intentionally causes death or bodily injury likely to cause death.

Option D: Grievous hurt is punishable by Sec. 320 IPC. Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for a period of twenty days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.

questions.solution:
When expressed as the percentage of body weight 20% of body weight is in ECF (1/3rd of 60%), and 40% of body weight is in ICF (2/3rd of 60%), 

The 60-40-20 rule is: 60% of body weight is water, of which 40% is ICF, and 20% is ECF.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with fever and painful swelling of the left eye. He is being treated for acute ethmoiditis for 5 days. questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of this patient is orbital cellulitis.

Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit posterior to the orbital septum. If left untreated it may progress to either a subperiosteal or orbital abscess. 

Ethmoidal sinusitis is the most common cause of orbital cellulitis in children.

Patients present with pain, lid edema, erythema, conjunctival chemosis, and axial proptosis. Decreased ocular motility and relative afferent pupillary defect can also be seen. A rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve.

Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is a paradoxical response of a pupil to a light stimulus. It is tested by the swinging flashlight test.

Other options:

Option A: Optic neuritis is an inflammatory and demyelinating disorder of the optic nerve in which patients present with symptoms such as sudden monocular vision loss, impaired color vision, and impaired depth perception.

Option B: Patients with cavernous sinus thrombosis present with edema in the mastoid region which is not seen in orbital cellulitis. Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a bilateral condition due to intercavernous communication. Patients can also present with ophthalmoplegia due to palsy of the 3rd,4th and 6th cranial nerves.

Option D: Preseptal cellulitis refers to infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. Patients present with painful periorbital swelling and there is no proptosis. Ocular movements and visual acuity are normal in patients with this condition.

In this type of conjunctivitis, there is inflammation of the inner and outer canthi with excoriation of skin and a collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles.

Oxytetracycline (1%),2-3 times a day for 10 to 14 days is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a thyroidectomy for a patient with a multinodular goiter. Damage to which structure is most likely to cause vocal cord paralysis?
questions.solution:
Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve will cause vocal cord paralysis.

All the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except for the cricothyroid are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve which is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

Since most of the laryngeal muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, the most appropriate answer would be recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Other options:

  • External laryngeal nerve: It supplies motor innervation to the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for controlling the tension of the vocal cords. Damage to this nerve can cause weakness or paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, leading to changes in voice quality and pitch. 
  • Internal laryngeal nerve: It provides sensory innervation to the larynx above the vocal cords. Damage to this nerve may result in decreased sensation in the upper part of the larynx
  • Superior laryngeal nerve: Similar to the external laryngeal nerve, damage to the superior laryngeal nerve can affect the function of the cricothyroid muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is not included in the triad of  Van der Hoeve syndrome?
questions.solution:
Icterus is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome

Van der Hoeve Syndrome Triad:

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta: A genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones that are prone to fractures.
  • Otosclerosis: An abnormal bone growth in the middle ear leading to hearing loss.
  • Blue Sclera: The white part of the eye appears blue or gray due to the thinness of the sclera, revealing the underlying choroidal veins.

Van der Hoeve syndrome primarily involves skeletal and auditory abnormalities, and jaundice is not a characteristic feature.

Icterus may indicate a different underlying pathology, such as liver dysfunction or hemolytic disorders, which should be evaluated separately.

questions.text: Identify the Ampulla of Vater in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked A in the image is the ampulla of Vater.

The bile duct and the pancreatic duct unite to form the hepatopancreatic ampulla (ampulla of Vater) within the second part of the duodenum, which opens at the major duodenal papilla.

Sometimes an accessory pancreatic duct is present, and opens into the minor duodenal papilla. It is about 2 cm proximal to the major duodenal papilla in the second part of the duodenum.

Clinical Note:

  • Familial adenomatous polyposis [APC gene defect] is associated with carcinoma of the Ampulla of Vater.
  • Duodenal villous adenomas are commonly found around the ampulla of Vater and they are premalignant.
  • Duodenal injuries with tissue loss distal to the major duodenal papilla and proximal to the superior mesenteric vessels are best treated by Roux-en-Y duodenojejunostomy.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient presented to the clinic with complaints of  episodic vertigo,  sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What is the possible clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is that of Meniere's disease.

It is also called endolymphatic hydrops.It is commonly seen in patients 35-60 years of age and male patients are more commonly affected than females.

The main pathology in Ménière’s disease is the distension of the endolymphatic system due to the increased volume of endolymph.

Accordingly, the typical history involves episodic attacks of true whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus. 

Examination:

  • Otoscopy - No abnormality seen in the tympanic membrane.
  • Nystagmus - Seen only during an acute attack. The quick component of nystagmus is towards the unaffected ear.
  • Tuning fork test - Indicate sensorineural hearing loss. Rinne's test is positive, Weber is lateralized to the better ear. Absolute bone conduction is reduced in the affected ear.

 Other options:

Option B: BPPV is not associated with hearing loss.

Option C: Syncope is associated with loss of consciousness.

Option D: Petrositis is not associated with episodic vertigo like in Meniere's disease.

questions.text: A patient was referred by a doctor to a tertiary center for a PET scan and the doctor was given money for the referral. What is this unethical act called?
questions.solution:
This unethical act of receiving a commission for referring a patient is referred to as Dichotomy. 

Dichotomy is an unethical act wherein a doctor receives a gift, commission or money for referring, recommending, or procuring a patient for any medical, surgical or other treatments. Fee splitting is unethical in India.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given features are consistent with Von Gierke's disease. It is the most common glycogen storage disease.

The enzyme deficient in this condition is glucose-6-phosphatase (common to both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis). Inheritance is autosomal recessive. 

Glycogen accumulation occurs in the liver and renal tubular cells. Clinical features include:

  • Severe hypoglycemia
  • Ketosis
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperuricemia

A definitive diagnosis is made using a liver biopsy. Fructose and galactose restriction in the diet is advised.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Virchow's triad?
questions.solution:
Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad. However, hyperviscosity states as in polycythemia vera may, in turn, cause small vessel stasis that may cause thrombosis.

Virchow's triad in thrombosis:

  1. Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability.
  2. Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury.
  3. Hypercoagulability of blood

These factors may promote thrombosis independently or in combination.
